newsitem.title: MACAU: Air Macau to add Chinese routes, get new planes.
newsitem.headline: Air Macau to add Chinese routes, get new planes.

text.p: Air Macau said on Thursday it plans to add three Chinese cities to its schedule and will take delivery of two new Airbus A321 aircraft next year.

The flag carrier of the Portuguese-administered enclave plans to launch daily flights to Haikou on Hainan Island and three flights a week to Wuhan in Hubei province and Qingdao in Shandong province "progressively from March next year", a company official said.
The airline now operates regular flights to Beijing, Shanghai and Xiamen as well as to Taipei and Kaohsiung in Taiwan and to Bangkok in Thailand.
Air Macau also said it will take delivery of one of the Airbus Industrie aircraft from International Lease Finance of the United States at the end of February and the other in April.
The airline -- a Sino-Portuguese joint venture that held its first flight on November 9, 1995 -- now has a fleet of two Airbus A321s and two A320s.
Air Macau flies the Portuguese flag until the enclave reverts to Chinese rule on December 20, 1999. It is 51 percent held by state-owned Air China and TAP-Air Portugal.
